title: 20120818_FND000_1.jpg
description:
The origin of money

Money fulfills three main functions. First, it must be a medium of exchange, easily traded for goods and services. Second, it must be a store of value, so that it can be saved and used for consumption in the future. Third, it must be a unit of account, a useful measuring-stick.

Some argue that money has its roots in the power of the state. Others claim the origin of money is a purely private matter: it would exist even if governments did not. AndÂ It was state intervention, not the private market, that made precious metals work as money.

Read more: http://www.economist.com/node/21560554
comments.comment: A good article. One thing that baffles me though is the use of rosary beads as money in British prisons. I've heard of cigarettes, mackerel and shower gel but these can all serve a function. Unless, of course, there is a higher spiritual dimension to prison that I'm overlooking...
